section.title: Choice
section.para: The deterministic choice operator prescribes that the left alternative should be tried before the right alternative, and that the latter is only used if the first fails. There are applications where it is not necessary to define the order of the alternatives. In those cases non-deterministic choice can be used.
The non-deterministic choice operator s1 + s2 chooses one of the two strategies s1 or s2 to apply, such that the one it chooses succeeds. If both strategies fail, then the choice fails as well.

Operationally one can imagine the choice operator to first try one strategy, and, if that fails, to try the other. The order in which this is done is undefined, i.e., arbitrarily chosen by the compiler.
